1.brief: a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
a cardinal number, eight (as if a surplus above the 'perfect' seven); also (as ordinal) eighth
a year (as a revolution of time)
Joshijah, the name of two Israelites
to reign; inceptively, to ascend the throne; causatively, to induct into royalty; hence (by implication) to take counsel
properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first
a year (as a revolution of time)
to reign; inceptively, to ascend the throne; causatively, to induct into royalty; hence (by implication) to take counsel
Jerushalaim or Jerushalem, the capital city of Palestine
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
a mother (as the bond of the family); in a wide sense (both literally and figuratively (like father))
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
Adajah, the name of eight Israelites

2.brief: to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
a road (as trodden); figuratively, a course of life or mode of action, often adverb
David, the youngest son of Jesse
father, in a literal and immediate, or figurative and remote application
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
the right hand or side (leg, eye) of a person or other object (as the stronger and more dexterous); locally, the south
properly, dark (as enveloped), i.e. the north; hence (by orientation), the left hand

a cardinal number, eight (as if a surplus above the 'perfect' seven); also (as ordinal) eighth
a year (as a revolution of time)

near, with or among; often in general, to

silver (from its pale color); by implication, money
